At that time, the World-Honored One arose from samÄdhi with ease and told Maitreya Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva:
Excellent, excellent!
You great beings!
All good men!

In order to draw near to the father of the world, in order to listen to the supramundane Dharma, in order to contemplate the principle of suchness, in order to cultivate the wisdom of suchness, you have come to the Buddha, making offerings and paying respect.
I will now expound the wonderful Dharma of the mind ground, guiding sentient beings to enter the Buddha's wisdom.
Such wonderful Dharma is expounded by the buddhas and tathÄgatas only after immeasurable eons.

The appearance of the TathÄgata in the world is extremely difficult to encounter, like the udumbara flower. Even if the TathÄgata appears in the world, it is also difficult to expound this wonderful Dharma.

All sentient beings are far from the great vehicle, the bodhisattva practices and vows, and head towards the enlightenment of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, weary of saá¹ƒsÄra and forever entering nirvÄá¹‡a, not delighting in the great vehicle's eternal bliss and wonderful fruits.

1. Not being in the wrong place, 2. Not being at the wrong time, 3. Not being the wrong vessel, 4. Not being the wrong Dharma.

Giving medicine according to the illness, causing one to recover, is precisely the tathÄgatas' unique virtue. ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas have not yet attained mastery, and the assembly of bodhisattvas is not the shared realm. For these causes and conditions, the correct path of enlightenment, the Dharma door of the mind ground, is difficult to see and difficult to hear.

If there are good sons and good women who hear this wonderful Dharma even once, and for a short while focus their thoughts and contemplate the mind, it will become an incense for the unsurpassed great enlightenment, and before long they will sit under the king of bodhi trees, on the adamantine jewel seat, and attain supreme perfect enlightenment.

I see the Tathagata emitting golden light, with the shadows manifesting the bodhisattvas' difficult and painful practices. I do not delight in the mind of practicing painful practices. Who can abide in birth and death forever, and experience various sufferings for the sake of sentient beings?

Having had this thought, he immediately rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, joined his palms in respect, and with different voices addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
We do not enjoy the practices of the bodhisattvas of the Mahayana, nor do we delight in hearing the sounds of difficult practices.
Why is this?
All the practices and vows of bodhisattvas are not knowing gratitude and repaying kindness.
Why is this?

Far away from parents, they go forth from home, giving their own wives and children to those who desire them, and according to their wishes, they give away their heads, eyes, marrow, and brains, enduring all the pain and suffering. For three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, they fully cultivate the perfections and the eighty-four thousand pÄramitÄ practices, transcending the flow of birth and death, and finally reaching the great bliss of bodhi.

It is not as good as heading towards the fruition of the two vehicles, cultivating the provisions for three lifetimes and a hundred kalpas, severing the causes of birth and death, realizing the fruition of nirvÄá¹‡a, and quickly attaining bliss, which is called repaying kindness.
At that time, the Buddha told the five hundred elders:
Excellent, excellent!

You have heard the praise of the Great Vehicle, and your minds have turned away from it, giving rise to wonderful meanings, benefiting and bringing peace to all sentient beings in the future who do not know gratitude.
Listen carefully, listen carefully, and consider it well. I will now explain for you the worldly and world-transcending places of kindness.
Good men!
What you have said is not yet the correct principle.
Why is it so?
There are four kinds of kindness in the world and beyond:
First, the kindness of parents, second, the kindness of sentient beings, third, the kindness of the king, and fourth, the kindness of the Three Jewels.
All sentient beings equally bear these four kinds of kindness.
Good man!
The kindness of parents means that the father has the kindness of compassion, and the mother has the kindness of mercy.
The kindness of the mother's mercy, if I were to dwell in the world for an eon, I would not be able to fully explain it. I will now proclaim a small portion for you.

Suppose someone, for the sake of merit, respectfully makes offerings to a hundred pure Brahmins, a hundred great sages with the five supernatural powers, and a hundred good friends, placing them in a magnificent hall made of the seven treasures, with a hundred thousand kinds of the finest delicacies, hanging various necklaces, precious garments, sandalwood and agarwood, and building various residences, with beds and bedding adorned with a hundred treasures, and medicines for treating various illnesses, and makes offerings to them single-mindedly for a hundred thousand eons;

It is not as good as abiding for a single thought with a mind of filial obedience, and with a small amount of material goods, providing for one's kind mother, and attending to her needs. Compared to the previous merits, it is not even a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.

The compassion of a mother in the world for her child is incomparable. Her kindness extends even before conception, beginning with the acceptance of the fetus and lasting for ten months. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, she undergoes various sufferings that cannot be expressed in words. Although she may enjoy sensual pleasures, food, and clothing, she does not give rise to attachment. Her thoughts of worry and care are always unceasing. She only thinks to herself about giving birth and gradually undergoes various sufferings, sorrowful day and night;
If there are difficulties in childbirth, it is like hundreds of thousands of blades coming to cut and carve her, or even lead to her death.
If there are no sufferings and difficulties, the joy and happiness of her relatives and family are inexhaustible.

It is like a poor woman who obtains a wish-fulfilling jewel. When her child makes a sound, it is like hearing music. The child sleeps on her chest and abdomen, and always plays on her left and right knees. From her chest and abdomen, a fountain of nectar emerges. The kindness of nurturing is as vast as the entire sky, and the virtue of compassion is incomparably great.
Nothing in the world is higher than mountains, yet the kindness of a mother surpasses even Mount Sumeru;
The great earth is foremost in the world, and the kindness of a mother is even greater than that.

If a son or daughter is unfilial and disobedient, causing their parents to give rise to resentment, if the mother utters evil words, the child will immediately fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.
There is no illness in the world more severe than a violent wind, and the signs of resentment are even faster than that;
All Tathagatas, Vajras, Devas, and those with the five supernatural powers cannot save and protect them.
If a good man or good woman relies on their mother's teachings and is obedient, all the gods will protect them and their blessings and happiness will be inexhaustible.
Such sons and daughters are called noble and of the type of heavenly beings. They may be Bodhisattvas who appear as sons and daughters to deliver sentient beings and benefit their parents.

If a good man or good woman wishes to repay their mother's kindness, even if they were to spend a kalpa each day for three times cutting their own flesh to nourish their parents, they still would not be able to repay even one day's worth of kindness.
Why is this?

All sons and daughters, while in the womb, suckle at the breast and drink their mother's blood, and after being born, before they are able to eat solid food, they drink their mother's milk, which amounts to one hundred and eighty hu. The mother gives her children the best flavors, and the most precious and wonderful clothes, without any discrimination based on foolishness, vulgarity, or love.

In the past, there was a woman who traveled far to another country, carrying her newborn child across the Ganges River. The water suddenly rose, and she was unable to proceed. Out of love and care, she did not abandon them, and mother and child both drowned.
Because of the power of her compassionate wholesome roots, she was immediately reborn in the highest heaven of the form realm and became the Great Brahma King.
For this reason, a mother has ten virtues:
First, she is called the great earth, because she is the support in the mother's womb.
Second, it is called the producer, because it can produce [the child] through experiencing various hardships.
Third, it is called the corrector, because it always uses its hands to regulate the five faculties of the child.
Fourth, it is called the nurturer, because it can nourish [the child] according to the appropriateness of the four seasons.
Fifth, it is called the wise one, because it can use skillful means to give rise to wisdom in the child.
Sixth, it is called the adornment, because it adorns [the child] with wonderful jewelry.
Seventh, it is called the one who provides comfort, because the mother's embrace is a place of rest for the child.
Eighth, it is called the instructor, because it skillfully guides the child.
Ninth, it is called the one who gives admonitions, because it uses good words and phrases to keep the child away from various evils.
Tenth, it is called the one who gives tasks, because it can entrust the family business to the child.
Good man!
Who is the richest in the world?
Who is the poorest?
If the compassionate mother is in the house, it is called wealth; if the compassionate mother is not there, it is called poverty;
When the compassionate mother is alive, it is called midday; when the compassionate mother dies, it is called sunset;
When the compassionate mother is alive, it is called moonlight; when the compassionate mother passes away, it is called dark night.
Therefore, you should diligently cultivate filial piety and support your parents. If a person makes offerings to the Buddha, the blessings are equal and no different.
You should repay the kindness of your parents like this.
Good man!

The kindness of sentient beings means that since beginningless time, all sentient beings have transmigrated through the five paths for hundreds of thousands of kalpas, and in many lifetimes they have been each other's parents;

Because they have been each other's parents, all men are compassionate fathers, and all women are compassionate mothers, because in past lives they had great kindness, just like the kindness of present parents, equal and without distinction.
Such past kindness is still unable to be repaid. Because of false karma, they give rise to various disagreements and compliance. Because of attachment, they become enemies.
Why is it so?

The light of the wisdom of recollecting past lives is obscured by ignorance, and one does not understand that in past lives one has been each other's parents, and that one should repay kindness by benefiting each other. Those who do not benefit are called unfilial.
For this reason,
all sentient beings at all times also have great kindness, which is truly difficult to repay.
Such matters are called the kindness of sentient beings.

As for the kindness of the king, his blessings and virtues are supreme. Although born among humans, he has sovereignty, and the celestial beings of the thirty-three heavens always give him strength and always protect him. Within his realm, from the mountains, rivers, and earth to the edge of the great ocean, it belongs to the king, and the blessings and virtues of one person surpass those of all sentient beings.
This great sage-king transforms with the right Dharma and can make sentient beings all attain peace and joy.
It is like all the halls and palaces in the world, with pillars as their foundation;
The people are prosperous and happy, with the king as their foundation, because they rely on the king.
It is also like the Brahma King who can give birth to myriad things, and the sage king who can give birth to the methods of governing the country and benefit sentient beings.
Just as the sun can illuminate the world, the sage king can also observe the people of the world and bring them peace and happiness.
If the king loses proper governance, the people have no one to rely on.

If he rules with righteousness, the eight great terrors will not enter his country, namely invasion by other countries, rebellion within his own borders, evil ghosts and diseases, famine in the country, untimely wind and rain, excessive wind and rain, solar and lunar eclipses, and strange occurrences in the stars.
Because the righteous rule of the human king benefits the people, these eight difficulties cannot invade.
It is like an elder who has only one child, loving and caring for him incomparably, always providing comfort and happiness, never leaving him day or night.
The great sage king of the country is also like this, treating all beings equally as if they were his only child, protecting them with a heart that never leaves them day or night.
Such a king who causes people to cultivate the ten wholesome deeds is called a virtuous lord;
If he does not cause people to cultivate them, he is called a non-virtuous lord.
Why is this so?

If in a king's realm there is one person who cultivates goodness, the merit they create is divided into seven parts. The person who creates the goodness obtains five parts, and the king of that country always obtains two parts, because the benefits of goodness are shared by the king who cultivates them together.
Creating the ten evil deeds is also like this, because the consequences are the same.
All the crops, fields, gardens, and forests that grow in the realm are also divided into seven parts in the same way.
If there is a king who achieves right views and rules the world according to the Dharma, he is called the lord of the gods.
Because he transforms the world with the good Dharma of the gods, the good gods and the world-protecting kings always come to add protection and guard the king's palace.
Although he dwells in the human realm, he practices the deeds of the gods, because his mind of reward and punishment is impartial.
The Dharma of all sage kings is like this, and such sage rulers are called righteous Dharma kings.
For these causes and conditions, they accomplish ten virtues:
First, they are called illuminators, because with the eye of wisdom they illuminate the world.
Second, they are called adorners, because they adorn the country with great blessings and wisdom.
Third, they are called givers of joy, because they give great peace and joy to the people.
Fourth, they are called conquerors of enemies, because all enemies naturally submit.
Fifth, they are called free from fear, because they can avert the eight difficulties and are free from terror.
Sixth, they are called employing the wise, because they gather wise people to discuss state affairs.
Seventh, they are called the basis of Dharma, because the myriad people live in peace and rely on the king.
Eighth, they are called upholders of the world, because they uphold the world with the Dharma of the heavenly kings.
Ninth, they are called masters of karma, because all good and evil karmas belong to the king.
Tenth, they are called lords of men, because all the people have the king as their lord.
All the kings of the world, by the blessings of their past lives, accomplish these ten kinds of supreme virtues.

The Great Brahma Heaven King and the Heaven of the Thirty-three will always assist the human king in receiving supreme and wonderful bliss. The kings of the rÄká¹£asas and various spirits, although not appearing in person, will secretly come to guard the king and his retinue.

'Our sagely king.'
The dragons and devas will be delighted, causing sweet rain to fall, the five grains to ripen, and the people to be prosperous and happy.

If he does not associate with various evil people, universally benefiting the world and all following the correct transformation, the wish-fulfilling jewel will certainly appear in the king's country. The neighboring kings will all come to submit, and humans and non-humans will all praise him.

If there are evil people in the king's realm who give rise to rebellious thoughts for a short while, such people's blessings will naturally decline, and after death they will fall into hell, transmigrate through the animal realm, and experience all kinds of suffering.
Why is this?
Because such people do not know the king's kindness and give rise to various evil rebellions, they receive such retribution.

If there are people who can cultivate good thoughts, respect and assist the virtuous king as if he were a Buddha, in this present life they will be peaceful, prosperous, and happy, and whatever they wish for will be fulfilled.
Why is this?
All the kings of the past have received the pure precepts of the TathÄgata and have always been peaceful and happy as human kings.
For this reason, whether it is contrary or in accordance, the fruits of retribution are all like echoes.
The kindness and virtues of the sage king are vast like this.
Good man!

The three jewels' kindness is called the inconceivable benefit and joy of sentient beings without rest. The bodies of all buddhas are truly wholesome and undefiled, realized through cultivating causes for innumerable great eons. The fruits of karma in the three realms are completely exhausted without remainder, a mountain of merit and virtue towering incomparably;
All sentient beings are unable to know it.

Merit and virtue are extremely deep, like the great ocean. Wisdom is unobstructed, equal to empty space. Spiritual powers and transformations fill the world. Light universally illuminates the ten directions and three times;
All sentient beings' afflictions and karmic hindrances do not even realize it.

Sinking and drowning in the sea of suffering, birth and death are endless. The three jewels appear in the world as great boat masters, able to cut off the flow of desire and ascend to the other shore. All wise ones all look up to them.
Good men and others!
There is only the one jewel of the Buddha endowed with three kinds of bodies:

The body of essence is beginningless and endless, free from all characteristics and beyond all conceptual proliferation, all-pervading and eternally abiding.
The body of enjoyment has two aspects: first, the enjoyment for oneself; second, the enjoyment for others.

First, the great perfect mirror cognition, which transforms the consciousness that matures results and attains this wisdom, like a great perfect mirror reflecting various forms.

Second, the cognition of equality, which transforms the consciousness of the view of self and attains this wisdom. Therefore, it is able to realize the equality of self and other, the nature of the two kinds of no-self. This is called the cognition of equality.

Fourth, the accomplishing wisdom, by transforming the five kinds of consciousness, one attains this wisdom, which is able to manifest all kinds of transformed bodies, causing sentient beings to perfect wholesome karma. For this reason, it is called the accomplishing wisdom.

Endowed with these six kinds of virtues, they are always able to benefit and delight all beings. This is called the inconceivable kindness of the Buddha Jewel.
At that time, the five hundred elders said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, within a single Buddha Jewel, countless transformation buddhas fill the world and benefit and delight beings.
For what causes and conditions do worldly beings mostly not see the Buddha and experience various sufferings?
The Buddha told the five hundred elders:
It is like the sun god emitting a hundred thousand lights to illuminate the world, yet there are the blind who do not see the light.
You, good men!
What do you think?
Does the sun god have any faults?
At that time, the elder said:

The Buddha said:

There are four kinds in the Dharma Jewel:
First, the Dharma of teaching; second, the Dharma of principle; third, the Dharma of practice; fourth, the Dharma of fruition.
All that is undefiled can destroy the hindrances of ignorance, afflictions, and karma. Sound, name, phrase, and text are called the Dharma of teaching;
The existence and non-existence of dharmas are called the Dharma of principle;
The practices of precepts, concentration, and wisdom are called the Dharma of practice;
The conditioned and unconditioned fruits are called the Dharma of fruition.
These four kinds are called the Dharma Jewel, guiding sentient beings out of the ocean of birth and death to reach the other shore.
Good man!
The teacher of the Buddhas is precisely the Dharma Jewel.
Why is it so?

The buddhas of the three times rely on the Dharma to practice, sever all hindrances, attain enlightenment, and benefit sentient beings throughout the future. For this reason, the tathÄgatas of the three times are always able to make offerings to the subtle Dharma treasures of the pÄramitÄs, let alone the sentient beings of the three realms who have not yet attained liberation, who are unable to respectfully make offerings to the subtle Dharma treasures?

In the past, I was once a Dharma-seeking king who entered a great fire pit to seek the true Dharma, forever severing birth and death and attaining great enlightenment.
Therefore, the Dharma treasure is able to destroy all the prisons of birth and death, just as the vajra can destroy myriad things;
The Dharma treasure is able to illuminate sentient beings in the darkness, just as the sun is able to illuminate the world;
The Dharma treasure is able to save sentient beings from poverty, just as the maá¹‡i jewel rains down myriad treasures;
The Dharma treasure is able to give sentient beings joy and pleasure, just as the heavenly drum delights the gods;
The Dharma Jewel is able to be the precious staircase for the heavenly beings, because by listening to the true Dharma one can be reborn in the heavens;
The Dharma Jewel is able to be the sturdy great ship, because it can ferry one across the sea of birth and death to the other shore;
The Dharma Jewel is like the Wheel-Turning Sage King, because it can eliminate the thieves of the three poisons and afflictions;
The Dharma Jewel is able to be the precious and wonderful clothing, because it covers the sentient beings who are without shame;
The Dharma Jewel is like the adamantine armor, because it can destroy the four demons and realize enlightenment;
The Dharma Jewel is like the sharp sword of wisdom, because it cuts off birth and death and liberates one from bondage;
The Dharma Jewel is precisely the precious carriage of the Three Vehicles, because it transports sentient beings out of the burning house;
The Dharma Jewel is like the bright lamp of all things, because it can illuminate the dark places of the three evil paths;
The Dharma Jewel is like the bow, arrow, spear, and halberd, because it can defend the country's borders and destroy the enemy;
The Dharma Jewel is like the guide on a treacherous road, because it skillfully leads sentient beings to the place of treasures.
Good man!
The wonderful Dharma spoken by the TathÄgatas of the three times has such inconceivable matters as these, which are called the inconceivable kindness of the Dharma Jewel.
Good man!
